I know of few T=
DD proponents that don't do some modicum of up-front  
design. The amount I=
've found I need to do is small, and a lot of it  
is in my head. What most=
 of us rail against is the notion that we need  
to produce a complete, hig=
hly detailed up-front design.

You're incorrectly assuming that TDD is just=
 about testing, or even  
testing+design, which its proponents suggest. Not=
 considering its  
impact on improving how to approach design (which can fe=
ed back in the  
ability to improve upon up-front design), if that's all we=
 got out of  
it, TDDing 100% of the time would seem to be reasonably expen=
sive.  
Particularly for someone who was very good at designing, like yours=
elf.

We also do a lot of "after the fact" design, i.e. we're continually  =

trying to stay cognizant of the design impacts of every few lines of  
cod=
e. We try to do something about it, as opposed to the crowd that  
presumes=
 their up-front design is perfect.

The bigger thing TDD does is enable ref=
actoring of code. Whether or  
not the design up front was good, the most s=
ignificant costs lie in  
the implementation and extended maintenance of th=
e system. If you ever  
get a chance to work on systems that are more than =
a couple years old,  
and where business demands keep coming, you'll find t=
hat's where the  
true costs are. Most code out there is just bad, and high=
ly, highly  
redundant.

Unfortunately, it's very dangerous for programmers=
 to start guessing  
where they don't need tests, particularly if they're n=
ot as highly  
skilled as you obviously are. They usually guess wrong. Lazi=
ness tends  
to take control of this guessing game, and not enough tests ge=
t  
written. Maybe that's not so bad, if we have enough integration tests  =

(most systems rarely do). But the bigger impact is that lack of tests  
si=
gnificantly increases the risk of keeping the code clean, and the  
system =
takes a much quicker route to complete degradation.

Try working on a C++ s=
ystem like this that's been around 10 years,  
that takes an hour just to b=
uild, and for which it takes hours to  
figure out where a simple chunk of =
code goes, and hours or days more  
to figure out whether or not you've bro=
ken something by making your  
simple change. Sweetly, and with great karma=
, the defects often crop  
up in the untested areas, where we thought we we=
re too smart to have  
needed tests.

I also get a lot of value out of test=
s that programmers crafted with  
the intent to help me understand what the=
 classes are about. I've had  
opportunities to work with systems that were=
 comprehensively covered  
with unit tests. It's a breeze to find what you'=
re looking for in such  
a system, as opposed to the typical nightmare of n=
avigating through a

 tests can

 exist.

ne.
